title: Classic Soda Fountains
description: Step up to the counter and test your memories of the beloved soda fountain era of drugstores and diners!

questions.question: What was the name of the person who operated the soda fountain at a drugstore?
questions.explanation: The soda jerk got the name from the jerking motion used to pull the draft arms of the soda fountain. It was a coveted job for young men in the 1940s and 1950s.

questions.question: What classic soda fountain treat combined soda water, flavored syrup, and a scoop of ice cream?
questions.explanation: The ice cream float (or ice cream soda) was a soda fountain staple, combining carbonated soda with a scoop of ice cream on top. Root beer floats were especially popular.

questions.question: What New York City soda fountain specialty combined chocolate syrup, milk, and seltzer water but contained no eggs or cream despite its name?
questions.explanation: The Egg Cream, a classic New York soda fountain drink, contains neither egg nor cream. It's made with chocolate syrup (traditionally Fox's U-Bet), milk, and seltzer water.

questions.question: What was a 'phosphate' at a soda fountain?
options: Flavored syrup mixed with carbonated water and acid phosphate
questions.explanation: A phosphate was a refreshing drink made by mixing flavored syrup with carbonated water and a dash of acid phosphate, which gave it a distinctive tangy flavor.

questions.question: What was the difference between a milkshake and a 'malt' at a soda fountain?
options: A malt added malted milk powder
questions.explanation: A malt (or malted milkshake) was made by adding malted milk powder to a standard milkshake, giving it a distinctive rich, slightly nutty flavor.

questions.question: What classic sundae featured vanilla ice cream, chocolate sauce, whipped cream, and a maraschino cherry?
questions.explanation: The Hot Fudge Sundae was the crown jewel of soda fountain desserts, featuring warm chocolate fudge sauce over cold vanilla ice cream, whipped cream, nuts, and a cherry on top.

questions.question: Where were soda fountains most commonly found in American towns from the 1920s through the 1960s?
questions.explanation: Soda fountains were most commonly located inside drugstores and pharmacies. The combination of a pharmacy and soda fountain was a fixture of Main Street America.

questions.question: What was a 'Suicide' or 'Graveyard' at the soda fountain?
options: A mix of every available soda flavor
questions.explanation: A Suicide (or Graveyard) was made by mixing a splash of every available soda flavor together. Kids loved ordering this wild combination at the fountain.

questions.question: What was the classic soda fountain dessert that featured a banana split lengthwise with three scoops of ice cream and various toppings?
questions.explanation: The Banana Split was invented in 1904 in Latrobe, Pennsylvania. It traditionally features a banana split lengthwise with chocolate, vanilla, and strawberry ice cream, plus assorted toppings.

questions.question: What type of seating was most iconic at a soda fountain counter?
options: Chrome swivel stools with vinyl seats
questions.explanation: Chrome swivel stools with round vinyl-covered seats lined the soda fountain counter. Spinning on these stools was a favorite activity for children while waiting for their treats.

questions.question: What was a 'Cherry Coke' at the soda fountain before it became a bottled product?
options: A Coca-Cola mixed with cherry juice
Coca-Cola with cherry flavoring syrup added by the soda jerk
questions.explanation: Before Cherry Coke was bottled in 1985, soda jerks would add a pump of cherry syrup to regular Coca-Cola at the fountain. It was a popular customization for decades.

questions.question: What glass container was used to serve milkshakes at the soda fountain, with the extra portion served alongside in the metal mixing cup?
questions.explanation: Milkshakes were served in tall, fluted fountain glasses, and the extra portion from the metal mixing cup was placed alongside so the customer got every last drop.

questions.question: Which Cherry syrup brand was most closely associated with old-fashioned soda fountain cherry phosphates and Cokes?
questions.explanation: Rose's Grenadine was the standard cherry-flavored syrup used at soda fountains for cherry phosphates, Cherry Cokes, and Shirley Temples throughout the mid-20th century.

questions.question: What was a 'Dusty Miller' at the soda fountain?
options: A chocolate sundae with malt powder
A vanilla milkshake with cookie crumbs
A root beer float with whipped cream
A sundae with chocolate ice cream and malt powder on top
questions.explanation: A Dusty Miller was a chocolate sundae sprinkled with malted milk powder, giving it a distinctive 'dusty' appearance and rich malt flavor.

questions.question: What non-alcoholic cocktail, made with ginger ale, grenadine, and a maraschino cherry, was named after a famous child actress?
questions.explanation: The Shirley Temple was named after the beloved child movie star and was the go-to fancy drink for children at restaurants and soda fountains throughout the 1930s and beyond.
